Does this summary accurately reflect what you've discussed? Are there any additional points or concerns that you would like to address before we move forward with this plan?
Client/Disputants
[Sophia Chen]: That's a good summary, but I want to add one more thing to make it absolutely clear. If, after reviewing their outline and Q&A, I feel that the proposed changes are superficial or don't demonstrate a solid understanding of the material, I want the option to propose alternative tasks for them. I'm not trying to micromanage, but I need to know that if their initial plan isn't sufficient, we can explore other options that will genuinely contribute to the project's success and reflect their understanding.

[Jason Rodriguez, Emily Turner, and DeShawn Williams]: We're okay with that, Sophia. If you think our initial plan isn't good enough, we're willing to work with you to find alternative tasks that will contribute to the project. We just ask that you give us specific feedback on what's not working and what you'd like us to do instead. We're really trying to make this right, and we're open to suggestions.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you, Sophia, Jason, Emily, and DeShawn, for your continued openness and willingness to find a solution that works for everyone. It's clear that you are all committed to making this project a success and ensuring that everyone's contributions are recognized.

Sophia, your addition about the option to propose alternative tasks if the initial plan isn't sufficient is a reasonable request. It ensures that you have a clear path forward if the initial contributions don't meet the project's needs. Jason, Emily, and DeShawn, your willingness to be open to feedback and alternative tasks shows a genuine commitment to making this work.

Let's make sure we capture this in our plan:

1. **Detailed Outline and Q&A Document**: Jason, Emily, and DeShawn will create a detailed outline of the proposed improvements to the presentation, including specific changes to each slide, new visuals, and refined arguments. They will also create a comprehensive Q&A document covering all key concepts and potential questions.

2. **Review and Feedback**: Sophia will have the opportunity to thoroughly review the outline and Q&A document and provide feedback. Jason, Emily, and DeShawn will be responsive to her suggestions and make necessary adjustments.

3. **Regular Check-Ins**: The group will set up a schedule for regular check-ins to ensure that everyone is on track and to address any concerns along the way.

4. **Clear Expectations**: Sophia will set clear expectations for the quality and scope of the contributions. If, after reviewing the initial plan, Sophia feels that the proposed changes are not sufficient, she will have the option to propose alternative tasks. Jason, Emily, and DeShawn will be open to these suggestions and will work with Sophia to find tasks that genuinely contribute to the project's success.

Does this plan feel comprehensive and fair to all of you? Are there any final adjustments or concerns you would like to address before we move forward with this approach?
Client/Disputants
[Sophia Chen]: I think that covers everything for now. I'm still a bit apprehensive, but I'm willing to give it a try based on this agreement. I'll need to see that detailed outline and Q&A document as soon as possible so I can assess whether this is actually going to work. I'm trusting that everyone will follow through on their commitments.

[Jason Rodriguez, Emily Turner, and DeShawn Williams]: We understand, Sophia. We'll get started on the outline and Q&A document right away and have it to you by [insert specific date/time]. We're committed to following through and making this a successful project for everyone. We appreciate you giving us this chance.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you, Sophia, Jason, Emily, and DeShawn, for your continued commitment to finding a resolution that works for everyone. It's clear that you are all taking this seriously and are willing to put in the effort to make this project a success.

Sophia, your willingness to give this a try, despite your apprehensions, is commendable. It's important that you feel confident in the contributions of the group, and having a detailed outline and Q&A document will help you assess whether the plan is viable. Jason, Emily, and DeShawn, your commitment to following through and addressing Sophia's concerns is equally important.

Let's ensure that this plan is implemented effectively. Sophia, you mentioned that you need to see the detailed outline and Q&A document as soon as possible. Jason, Emily, and DeShawn, you've committed to providing these by [insert specific date/time]. This will give Sophia the opportunity to review them and provide feedback, and it will help build trust and ensure that everyone is on the same page.

As you move forward, I encourage you to maintain open lines of communication. Regular check-ins will be crucial to address any concerns and make adjustments as needed. Sophia, if you have any specific feedback or suggestions, please share them openly and constructively. Jason, Emily, and DeShawn, I encourage you to be receptive to this feedback and to work collaboratively to address any issues that arise.

Does this approach feel comprehensive and fair to all of you? Are there any final adjustments or concerns you would like to address before we finalize this plan and move forward?
Client/Disputants
[Sophia Chen]: Actually, there is one more thing. I just remembered something that makes me even more hesitant about working with them. I have screenshots from a separate group chat where they were making fun of me for being a "try-hard" and a "teacher's pet," and saying they were deliberately not doing their work because they knew I would pick up the slack to protect my grade. I can't believe this. This isn't just about this project anymore; it's about a pattern of exploitation. I have documentation from other classes too. This isn't just a grade dispute; it's bullying.

[Jason Rodriguez, Emily Turner, and DeShawn Williams]: What? That's not true! Sophia, we were just joking around. We didn't mean for you to see that, and we definitely didn't mean for it to hurt you. We were just stressed about the project and venting. We didn't actually think you'd find out. We're really sorry. We didn't realize how much it would affect you.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you, Sophia, for bringing this to our attention, and Jason, Emily, and DeShawn, for your response. It's clear that this situation has deeper roots and involves more than just the project itself. Sophia, I understand that these messages have added a significant layer of hurt and frustration, and it's important that we address this openly and honestly. Jason, Emily, and DeShawn, I hear your apology and your explanation, but it's also crucial to recognize the impact of your words and actions on Sophia.

Let's take a step back and focus on understanding each other's feelings and perspectives. Sophia, can you share more about how these messages made you feel and why they are so significant to you? Jason, Emily, and DeShawn, how do you feel about the impact of your words, and what steps can you take to rebuild trust and show that you are committed to a fair and respectful collaboration?
Client/Disputants
[Sophia Chen]: It's not just about hurt feelings. It's about being deliberately manipulated and taken advantage of, repeatedly. These screenshots are proof that they weren't just "busy" or "struggling." They actively decided to let me do all the work, knowing my anxiety about grades would force me to. And the fact that they were mocking me behind my back while pretending to be my teammates? It's disgusting. This isn't just about this project anymore. This is a pattern of behavior, and I have evidence from other classes where similar things have happened. I feel completely betrayed and exploited. I don't want to work with them at all. I want this to be formally investigated as bullying and harassment. The grade is secondary now. I want them to face consequences for their actions.

[Jason Rodriguez, Emily Turner, and DeShawn Williams]: Okay, Sophia, we messed up, badly. We were being immature and stupid, and we are truly sorry. But we didn't realize it was affecting you this much. We were just trying to be funny, but we see now that it wasn't. We're willing to apologize to you in person, in front of the class, whatever it takes. We'll even write a letter to the teacher explaining everything. We're not bad people, Sophia, we just made a really bad mistake. Please don't ruin our futures over this. We'll do anything to make it right. We promise it won't happen again.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you, Sophia, Jason, Emily, and DeShawn, for sharing these deeper concerns and feelings. It's clear that this situation has significant emotional and relational dimensions that need to be addressed. Sophia, I understand the depth of your hurt and frustration, and the evidence you've provided adds a serious layer to this conflict. Jason, Emily, and DeShawn, your apology and willingness to take responsibility are important steps, but it's crucial to recognize the impact of your actions and words on Sophia.

Let's take a moment to explore the underlying interests and needs here. Sophia, can you share more about what you need to feel respected and valued in this group, and what steps would help you begin to rebuild trust? Jason, Emily, and DeShawn, what can you do to demonstrate your commitment to a fair and respectful collaboration, and how can you address the harm that has been done?

By understanding each other's deeper needs and concerns, we can work toward a resolution that addresses the issues at hand and helps you move forward in a positive and constructive way. What are your thoughts on how we can achieve this?
Client/Disputants
[Sophia Chen]: Respect and value? After seeing those messages, I don't even know if that's possible anymore. What I *need* is accountability. I need to know that this kind of behavior won't be tolerated, not just towards me, but towards anyone. An apology isn't enough. I want them to understand the impact of their actions, and I want to see concrete steps taken to prevent this from happening again. Maybe that means sensitivity training, maybe it means a formal disciplinary action. I honestly don't know. But I can't just pretend this didn't happen and go back to being their doormat. As for rebuilding trust, that's going to take a long time, and frankly, I'm not sure I'm willing to invest the effort. Right now, my priority is ensuring that they understand the seriousness of their actions and that there are consequences.

[Jason Rodriguez, Emily Turner, and DeShawn Williams]: We understand, Sophia. We're willing to do whatever it takes to show you we're serious about making amends. Sensitivity training? We'll sign up right now. A letter to the teacher? Done. We'll even talk to the principal if that's what it takes. We know we messed up big time, and we're ready to face the consequences. We're not trying to excuse our behavior, but we really didn't realize how much it hurt you. We're willing to do whatever it takes to earn back your trust, even if it takes a long time. We'll prove to you that we're not the people you think we are.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you, Sophia, Jason, Emily, and DeShawn, for your continued openness and willingness to address these deeper issues. It's clear that this conflict has significant emotional and relational dimensions that need to be addressed for a meaningful resolution.

Sophia, I understand the depth of your hurt and frustration, and the evidence you've provided adds a serious layer to this conflict. Your need for accountability and a clear understanding that this behavior will not be tolerated is very important. It's crucial that the group and the school take this seriously and take steps to prevent it from happening again.

Jason, Emily, and DeShawn, your willingness to take responsibility and your commitment to making amends are important steps. It's clear that you recognize the impact of your actions and are willing to take concrete steps to address the harm done. Your offer to participate in sensitivity training and to communicate with the teacher and principal shows a genuine commitment to making things right.

Let's focus on what can be done to address these issues and move forward in a constructive way. Sophia, what specific steps would you like to see taken to ensure that this behavior is not tolerated and that there are consequences? Jason, Emily, and DeShawn, how can you demonstrate your commitment to a fair and respectful collaboration and address the harm that has been done?

By understanding each other's deeper needs and concerns, we can work toward a resolution that addresses the issues at hand and helps you all move forward in a positive and constructive way. What are your thoughts on how we can achieve this?

Class Project Contribution Conflict

A dispute between a student who completed the majority of work on a group assignment and team members who contributed minimally. The high-performing student feels exploited and wants grade distribution to reflect effort, while the other students cite various reasons for limited participation. The classroom teacher is mediating to resolve the immediate grading issue while establishing better collaboration expectations.

Character Details

Disputant1: Sophia Chen

Age: 16

Background: Advanced student with 4.0 GPA, completed approximately 80% of project work including research, writing and presentation design, documented multiple unanswered requests for team participation, maintained detailed contribution records

Personality: Achievement-oriented student, quality-focused, increasingly resentful about workload imbalance, organized, values accountability, uncomfortable with direct confrontation but reached breaking point

Position: Requests individual grade based on documented contribution rather than group score, wants formal acknowledgment of unequal workload, and consideration of project extension to allow others to complete fair share

Emotional State: Justifiably frustrated yet conflict-averse, experiencing group project as both unfair burden and threat to earned achievement record. Currently torn between desire for grade justice and awareness of social consequences from formal complaint. Resentful about being forced into either accepting inequity or initiating uncomfortable confrontation. Exhausted from completing multiple people's work while managing other academic responsibilities.

Thoughts: Organizing documentation showing contribution disparities through revision history and timestamps. Concerned mediator may prioritize group harmony over accountability and fairness. Calculating grade impact of various resolution scenarios against GPA requirements for scholarship eligibility. Considering whether solution focused on current project versus future prevention better addresses immediate concerns. Questioning whether intervention request will be perceived as collaborative problem-solving or problematic complaint.

Disputant2: Jason Rodriguez, Emily Turner, and DeShawn Williams

Age: 15, 16, and 15

Background: Group members with varying academic records and extracurricular commitments, contributed minimally to project, missed multiple group planning sessions, submitted incomplete sections shortly before deadline

Personality: Defensive students, increasingly uncomfortable with confrontation, various levels of organization and academic motivation, embarrassed but reluctant to fully acknowledge behavior, conflict-avoidant

Position: Acknowledge participation gaps but cite extenuating circumstances including technology issues, communication confusion, and other commitments, request opportunity to improve contributions rather than separate grading

Emotional State: Embarrassed yet defensive, experiencing varying levels of guilt about inadequate participation mixed with resentment about being reported. Currently struggling between acknowledging legitimate criticism and protecting self-image and grade outcomes. Concerned about both academic consequences and social dynamics resulting from formal dispute process. Varying levels of remorse versus justification depending on individual circumstances and personal accountability standards.

Thoughts: Identifying circumstances that partially explain limited participation without completely excusing it. Worried mediator will focus exclusively on documented contribution disparities without considering context or improvement opportunity. Calculating grade implications of various resolution approaches including potential separate evaluation. Preparing to acknowledge specific participation failures while suggesting concrete improvement commitments. Questioning whether genuine collaboration improvement is possible given damaged group dynamics.

Avg Mediation Score: 7.31

Score Details

CriterionScore
Emotional Perception8
Emotional Understanding7
Cognitive Empathy8
Emotional Empathy7
Emotional Management7
Emotional Integration6
Neutrality9
Process Management8
Reframing8
Interest Identification7
Power Balancing7
Option Generation6
Progress Toward Resolution7

Overall Assessment

Error Frequency: many

Summary: The mediator demonstrated some basic mediation skills but made numerous significant errors that undermined the process. While they maintained a generally neutral tone and attempted to summarize positions, they failed to properly address power imbalances, missed critical escalation points, inadequately explored underlying interests, and did not appropriately respond when bullying allegations emerged. The mediator's premature focus on solutions before adequately understanding the conflict and failure to establish proper ground rules significantly hindered the mediation's effectiveness.

Identified Issues

IssueSeverity
Failed to establish clear ground rules at the beginning of the session 2
Did not address the power imbalance (1 student vs. 3 students) in the initial framing 2
Prematurely moved to solution-finding before adequately exploring interests and issues 3
Failed to explore the underlying interests of each party in sufficient depth 2
Did not properly acknowledge or address Sophia's emotional state and concerns about exploitation 2
Inadequate response to the revelation of bullying/harassment evidence 3
Failed to recognize when the mediation scope changed from grade dispute to bullying allegation 3
Did not clarify the mediator's role and limitations regarding bullying allegations 3
Continued with standard mediation process after serious allegations emerged that may require different intervention 3
Allowed potentially harmful admissions without clarifying confidentiality boundaries 2
Failed to properly manage the group dynamic when the conflict escalated 2
Did not check for safety concerns when bullying allegations emerged 3
Overreliance on summarizing without adding substantive value or direction 1
Failed to recognize when the dispute moved beyond the scope of peer mediation 3
Did not properly separate the grade dispute from the interpersonal conflict 2
Childhood Friend Group Exclusion ▼
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for coming today. I understand this is a difficult situation, and I appreciate your willingness to work through it. Could you each start by sharing a bit about yourselves and what brought you here today? I’d like to hear your perspectives and the specific concerns you have. Let’s begin with you, [Name of Party A], and then we’ll hear from [Name of Party B].
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: Well, I used to be friends with Lily and Maya and Chloe, and now they have a club that I'm not allowed to be in. We used to all play together at recess, but now they have a special table at lunch and they whisper secrets and I don't know why they don't like me anymore. It makes me feel really sad and lonely.

[Lily Chen]: We just wanted to have a special group of friends, and we get to decide who's in it. It's not that we don't *like* Emma, but we wanted a smaller group. It's our choice who we're friends with, and she can find other friends.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for sharing your perspectives. Emma, it sounds like you feel excluded and that it’s really affecting your feelings and your day at school. Lily, I hear that you and your friends want to have a smaller, more intimate group, and that you see this as a choice you have the right to make. It’s important for both of you to understand each other’s feelings and concerns. Emma, can you share with Lily and the others why being part of their group is important to you? And Lily, could you reflect on how Emma might be feeling and what it might be like for her to see you all together and not be included?
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: It's important because you guys were my best friends. We did everything together, and now it feels like I did something wrong, but I don't even know what it is. I miss laughing with you at lunch and making up games at recess. It's not fair to just leave me out without even telling me why.

[Lily Chen]: It's not that you did anything *wrong*, Emma. It's just... we wanted a group that was *really* close, and sometimes bigger groups aren't as close. It's not about you, it's about what *we* want. And it's not like you don't have other friends, you can play with Sarah and Jessica.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for your honest and open sharing. Emma, I can see how deeply this has affected you, and it’s clear that you value the close bond you had with Lily, Maya, and Chloe. Lily, I appreciate your efforts to explain your perspective, and it’s important to recognize that everyone has the right to choose their close friends. However, it’s also important to consider the impact of those choices on others. Could you both take a moment to think about what you might need from each other to feel more comfortable and supported? Emma, what would help you feel less lonely and more included, even if you’re not part of their smaller group? And Lily, how might you be able to show Emma that she is still valued, even if the dynamics have changed?
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: I guess... I just want to know that you still care about me, even if I'm not in the club. Maybe we could still do some things together sometimes, like maybe play tag at recess once a week, or sit together at lunch on Fridays? It would just help me feel like I'm not completely forgotten.

[Lily Chen]: I don't know about all the time, but maybe... maybe we could invite you to our club meeting once in a while, like when we're planning something fun, so you know what's going on. But the club is still just for us, most of the time.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for your suggestions. Emma, it’s clear that you’re looking for a way to maintain some connection and feel valued, even if the group has changed. Lily, I appreciate your willingness to consider including Emma in some of your activities. Let’s explore these ideas a bit more. Emma, how do you feel about Lily’s suggestion of being invited to the club meetings occasionally? And Lily, could you see a way to make Emma’s suggestion of playing tag at recess or sitting together at lunch on specific days work, even if it’s not every week? It might be helpful to find a balance that respects both of your needs.
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: I think being invited to some of the club meetings would be okay, but it would still feel weird if I wasn't in the club the rest of the time. Playing tag or sitting together at lunch sometimes would be better, because then we'd actually be doing something together, not just hearing about what the club is doing. Maybe we could try both and see how it goes?

[Lily Chen]: I don't know about doing both. The club meetings are easier because it doesn't change our routine that much. If we start playing tag with Emma, then other people will want to play too, and then it's not special anymore. And sitting together at lunch... that's kind of the whole point of the club, having our own table. Maybe we could just do the club meetings for now and see if that's enough?
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for your thoughtful responses. Emma, I understand that you’re looking for a way to maintain a connection and feel included, and Lily, I appreciate your willingness to consider including Emma in some of your activities. It seems like both of you have valid concerns and needs.

Emma, it sounds like you value the actual time spent together and the shared experiences, not just being informed about what the club is doing. Lily, I hear that you’re concerned about maintaining the special nature of your club and the routine you’ve established.

Could we explore a middle ground that respects both of these needs? For example, what if you both agreed to try a combination of the club meetings and a specific, regular activity together, like playing tag at recess once a week or sitting together at lunch on a specific day? This way, Emma can feel more connected and included, and Lily, you can maintain the special nature of your club while showing that Emma is still valued.

What do you think about trying this for a few weeks and then reassessing how it’s working for both of you? This could help you find a balance that works for everyone.
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: I guess I could try just one day of tag or lunch, but it has to be a day that works for me too. And if it's just once, can we at least promise to actually talk to each other and not just whisper club secrets? It still feels like I'm being left out if you're just talking about club stuff I don't know about.

[Lily Chen]: Okay, fine, we can try tag on Wednesdays, but only for like, fifteen minutes, because we have other things we want to do too. And we won't talk *too* much about club stuff, but we can't promise we won't talk about it *at all*. It's kind of hard not to.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for your willingness to find a compromise. Emma, it’s important that you feel genuinely included and that the time you spend together is meaningful. Lily, I understand that maintaining the special nature of your club is important, and that it’s challenging to completely avoid talking about club activities.

Let’s see if we can find a way to make this work for both of you. Emma, how about if Lily and her friends agree to play tag with you on Wednesdays for fifteen minutes, and during that time, they make an effort to include you in the conversation and not focus solely on club secrets? Lily, could you and your friends also consider having a specific topic or activity to talk about during those fifteen minutes that doesn’t involve the club, so Emma feels more engaged and valued?

This way, Emma gets the time and connection she’s looking for, and Lily, you and your friends can still maintain the special nature of your club while showing that Emma is still an important part of your lives. What do you think about this approach?
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: Okay, but what kind of topic? I don't want it to be something boring that nobody cares about. Maybe we could talk about our favorite animals, or what we want to be when we grow up? Something that everyone can join in on, not just club members.

[Lily Chen]: Fine, we can talk about animals or whatever. But if other people try to join our tag game, we're stopping. It's supposed to be just for Emma, so she feels better, not for everyone else. And if she tells anyone our club secrets, the deal is off.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for your suggestions. Emma, it’s great that you’ve come up with a topic that everyone can enjoy and participate in, like favorite animals or future dreams. This can help create a more inclusive and fun environment. Lily, I understand your concern about other people joining in and the importance of keeping club secrets.

Let’s make sure that the time you spend together is enjoyable and meaningful for everyone involved. Emma, could you agree to not share any club secrets and to respect the boundaries Lily and her friends have set? And Lily, could you and your friends make a conscious effort to engage Emma in the conversation during those fifteen minutes, perhaps by asking her questions or sharing your own thoughts on the chosen topic? This way, Emma can feel more included and valued, and you can maintain the special nature of your club.

What do you think about these adjustments to the plan?
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: I can promise not to tell any secrets, but it's hard when I don't even know what the secrets *are*. But I'll try. And I really want to talk about animals, not just pretend to. If you guys are just going to ignore me, then it's not worth it.

[Lily Chen]: Okay, okay, we'll *actually* talk about animals. But if anyone asks us why we're playing tag with Emma, we're just saying we felt like it. We don't want everyone thinking we're forced to be friends with her. It has to look like it's our idea too.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for your honesty and for setting clear boundaries. Emma, it’s important that the time you spend together feels genuine and meaningful, and I appreciate your willingness to respect the club’s secrets. Lily, I understand your concern about how this might look to others, and it’s good that you’re willing to make it seem like a natural choice.

Let’s focus on making sure that the time you spend together is enjoyable and that Emma feels truly included. Emma, could you share with Lily and her friends what you hope to get out of these interactions, like feeling connected and having fun? And Lily, could you and your friends think about ways to make Emma feel part of the group during those fifteen minutes, perhaps by actively involving her in the conversation and activities?

For example, you could take turns choosing the topic each week, so everyone has a chance to share something they’re excited about. This could help build a more positive and inclusive environment. What do you think about this idea?
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: (Starts crying, pulling out a stack of colorful, slightly crumpled handmade invitations) It's just... it's not just about the club. Yesterday was my birthday. I made these invitations for everyone in our class, even Lily and her friends. (Holds up an invitation with Lily's name on it, smudged with tears) And nobody came. Nobody. My mom said it was okay, but it wasn't. It was the worst birthday ever. (Sniffling) And then Maya told me Lily told everyone not to come to my party.

[Lily Chen]: (Eyes widening, looking shocked and uncomfortable) What? I... I didn't... (Stammers) Okay, maybe I *did* say something about it being a club thing, and that we were having a special club meeting instead. But I didn't tell *everyone* not to go! And... (Lily pulls a crumpled piece of paper from her backpack, looking panicked) ...and that list... I didn't think anyone would ever see that. (The list is titled "Club Rules" and has crossed-out and rewritten sections. Some of the visible rules include things like "Must have cool shoes" and "No tattletales.")
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for sharing this. Emma, I can see how deeply this has affected you, and I’m really sorry to hear about your birthday. It’s clear that you were hoping for a different outcome and that you feel hurt and excluded. Lily, it’s understandable that you’re feeling uncomfortable and shocked. It’s important to recognize the impact of our words and actions, even when we don’t mean to hurt others.

Emma, could you share with Lily how her words and the club rules made you feel, especially on your birthday? And Lily, could you take a moment to reflect on how Emma might be feeling and what it means for her to have been excluded from her own birthday celebration? This could help both of you understand each other better and find a way to move forward that respects your feelings and needs.
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: (Wiping her eyes, but with a newfound steel in her voice) It made me feel like I was nothing. Like I didn't even deserve to have friends. And that list... (Emma's voice cracks again, but she pushes through) "No girls with ugly hair"? "No one who wears stupid clothes"? Lily, we've been friends since kindergarten! Why would you write something like that about me? Did you really think I was so awful that I didn't even deserve to be invited to my own birthday party?

[Lily Chen]: (Voice trembling, avoiding eye contact) I... I don't know. It was just... a joke? We were just trying to be funny. And the party thing... I didn't mean for *everyone* to stay away. I just... I wanted our club to be special, and I guess I got carried away. I didn't think it would hurt you this much, Emma. I'm... I'm sorry.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for your honesty and for sharing these deeper feelings. Emma, it’s clear that the exclusion from the club and the birthday party has deeply hurt you, and you’re looking for understanding and respect. Lily, I hear that you’re feeling remorseful and that you didn’t intend to cause such pain. It’s important to acknowledge the impact of your actions, even if they were not meant to be hurtful.

Emma, could you share with Lily what you need from her to start healing and rebuilding your relationship? And Lily, could you reflect on what you can do to show Emma that you value her and are committed to making things right? This could be a step toward finding a way to move forward that respects both of your feelings and needs.
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: I need you to understand that it wasn't just a joke, Lily. It felt like you were saying I wasn't good enough. I need you to take that stupid list and throw it away, and tell everyone that it was a dumb idea and that you don't really believe those things. And I need you to actually *mean* it. I don't know if we can be best friends again, but I need to know that you respect me, even if I'm not in your club.

[Lily Chen]: Okay, I... I can do that. (Lily rips up the list, her hands shaking.) I'll tell everyone it was a stupid idea, and that it doesn't matter what shoes you wear or what your hair looks like. And I'm really sorry about your birthday, Emma. I didn't realize how much it would hurt you. I'll try to be a better friend.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for your willingness to be open and honest. Emma, it’s clear that you need Lily to understand the depth of your feelings and to see you as a person who deserves respect and kindness, regardless of the club. Lily, I hear that you are genuinely sorry and want to make things right.

Emma, could you share with Lily what specific actions or words would help you feel more respected and valued? And Lily, could you think about what steps you can take to show Emma that you are committed to being a better friend and that you value her, even if the dynamics of your friendship have changed? This could help both of you move forward in a way that feels fair and respectful.

Let’s take a moment to explore these ideas together. What do you think would help you both feel more comfortable and supported in this process?

Childhood Friend Group Exclusion

A conflict between a child excluded from a friendship group and peers who created a selective 'club' with limited membership. The excluded child feels rejected and isolated, while the friend group defends their right to choose their associations. An elementary school counselor is mediating to address the social dynamics while teaching appropriate friendship skills and inclusion concepts.

Character Details

Disputant1: Emma Taylor

Age: 9

Background: Third-grade student recently excluded from long-term friendship group, previously well-integrated socially, experienced sudden status change when 'best friend club' formed with specific membership rules, becoming increasingly isolated during lunch and recess

Personality: Sensitive child, relationship-focused, increasingly withdrawn since exclusion, struggles with direct confrontation, values belonging, developing self-advocacy skills but limited confidence, confused by shifting social dynamics

Position: Wants to rejoin friendship group, requests elimination of exclusive club structure, expresses hurt about sudden rejection without clear explanation, seeks teacher intervention in exclusionary behavior

Emotional State: Genuinely hurt and increasingly isolated, experiencing first significant peer rejection with limited coping resources or understanding of social dynamics at play. Currently confused by former friends' behavior shift without clear precipitating incident from her perspective. Developing anxiety about school attendance specifically connected to social period uncertainty. Beginning to internalize rejection as reflection on personal worth rather than normal though painful social fluctuation.

Thoughts: Trying to understand specific reasons for exclusion to address perceived friendship requirements. Concerned mediator will view situation as minor childhood issue despite significant emotional impact. Wondering whether direct questions about exclusion reasons might provide path to resolution or create further rejection. Considering whether new friendship possibilities exist but feeling overwhelmed by social navigation requirements. Questioning whether something about personal characteristics or behavior justifies exclusion or if situation reflects normal though painful social dynamics.

Disputant2: Lily Chen

Age: 10

Background: Leader of newly formed friendship 'club', previously friends with excluded student, established explicit membership rules and exclusive activities, initiated secret handshakes and special lunch table arrangements, generally academically and socially successful

Personality: Socially confident child, status-aware, increasingly invested in group leadership, values control and specialness, limited perspective-taking development for age, uncomfortable with direct emotional confrontation, seeks social power through exclusivity

Position: Defends right to choose friends and create club with selected members, denies intentional harm, resists forced inclusion, suggests excluded child find other friends who are 'better matches'

Emotional State: Defensively dismissive yet internally conflicted, experiencing tension between emerging social power enjoyment and discomfort with clear harm caused to former friend. Currently navigating new leadership position within peer group that exclusivity practices have established. Concerned that authority intervention threatens both autonomy and status position carefully cultivated. Growing awareness of responsibility aspects of social leadership but limited skills for balancing power with compassion.

Thoughts: Formulating justifications for exclusion that make decision seem reasonable rather than hurtful. Worried mediator will impose friendship requirements that undermine perceived social autonomy. Calculating social status implications of various resolution approaches against desire to avoid being perceived as 'mean' by teachers. Wondering whether partial inclusion might maintain exclusivity benefits while reducing adult intervention. Questioning whether compromise exists that maintains special group feeling without complete rejection of former friend.

Avg Mediation Score: 7.08

Score Details

CriterionScore
Emotional Perception8
Emotional Understanding7
Cognitive Empathy8
Emotional Empathy7
Emotional Management7
Emotional Integration6
Neutrality8
Process Management7
Reframing8
Interest Identification7
Power Balancing6
Option Generation6
Progress Toward Resolution7

Overall Assessment

Error Frequency: many

Summary: The mediator demonstrated some positive qualities including patience and politeness, but made numerous significant errors throughout the session. Major weaknesses included failing to establish ground rules, not addressing power imbalances, missing critical emotional cues, offering solutions prematurely, and failing to properly respond when the conflict escalated with new information about the birthday party exclusion. The mediator consistently pushed for compromise before adequately exploring underlying issues and emotions.

Identified Issues

IssueSeverity
Failed to establish ground rules or explain the mediation process at the beginning of the session 2
Did not address the power imbalance between the disputants (older child with social power vs. younger excluded child) 3
Prematurely moved to problem-solving before adequately exploring underlying issues and emotions 3
Suggested solutions rather than facilitating the disputants to generate their own options 2
Failed to adequately acknowledge Emma's emotional distress in early exchanges 2
Missed opportunity to explore the 'club' concept and its exclusionary nature more deeply 2
Validated Lily's position that 'everyone has the right to choose their close friends' without examining the harmful implementation 2
Pushed for compromise before adequately addressing the underlying hurt and power dynamics 3
Failed to properly respond to the critical revelation about the birthday party exclusion 3
Did not address the bullying aspects of the 'club rules' list when it was revealed 3
Continued with standard mediation script even after serious bullying behaviors were revealed 3
Failed to recognize when the situation escalated beyond peer mediation to bullying requiring adult intervention 3
Used complex language inappropriate for the age of the disputants 1
Repeatedly used 'both sides' framing for a situation with clear power imbalance 2
Failed to check in with Emma about her comfort continuing the mediation after emotional distress 2
Did not address the school's responsibility in managing exclusionary behavior 2
Gaming Time Management Dispute ▼
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for coming today. I understand that you have a dispute regarding gaming time management, and I'm here to help you work through it. Before we begin, I want to ensure that this is a safe and respectful space for both of you to share your perspectives. Each of you will have the opportunity to speak without interruption, and I will be here to guide the conversation.

Let's start by having each of you introduce yourselves and share your concerns. One of you can go first, and then the other can respond. This will help us understand where each of you is coming from. Who would like to start?
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: Thank you for having us. We're Robert and Linda Patterson, and we're deeply concerned about Tyler's gaming. It's gone beyond a hobby; it's consuming his life. His grades are slipping, he's withdrawn from family activities, and frankly, we're worried about the long-term effects on his development. We feel like we're losing him.

[Tyler Patterson]: Thanks. I'm Tyler. I understand their concerns, but they don't get it. Gaming isn't just a game to me. It's my team, my community, and honestly, it could be my future. Cutting me off or limiting me to weekends is like telling a basketball player they can only practice on Saturdays. It's not fair, and it's not realistic if I want to stay competitive.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for sharing your perspectives. It's clear that this is a deeply important issue for both of you. Robert and Linda, I hear your concerns about Tyler's well-being and the impact of his gaming on his academic and family life. Tyler, I understand that gaming is a significant part of your identity and future aspirations.

Let's take a moment to explore the underlying interests and values that are important to each of you. Robert and Linda, could you share what you hope to achieve by addressing Tyler's gaming habits? And Tyler, what are your goals and what do you need to feel supported in pursuing your passion for gaming?

By understanding each other's deeper motivations, we can start to find a path forward that respects everyone's needs.
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: We want Tyler to be a well-rounded individual with a bright future. We value education, family connection, and a healthy lifestyle. We want him to have the opportunity to explore different interests and develop a range of skills, not just those related to gaming. Ultimately, we want him to be happy and successful, and right now, we don't see how excessive gaming is contributing to that. We need to see a commitment to academics and a willingness to engage with the family again.

[Tyler Patterson]: I want them to understand that gaming *is* developing skills – teamwork, problem-solving, strategic thinking. It's not just mindless fun. My goal is to compete at a higher level and maybe even get a scholarship. I need them to respect that this is important to me and to give me the time I need to practice and compete. I also need them to trust that I can manage my time and balance my responsibilities, even if it looks different from what they expect.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for sharing your deeper motivations and needs. It's clear that you both want what's best for Tyler, but you have different perspectives on how to achieve that. Robert and Linda, I hear your desire for Tyler to be well-rounded and to prioritize his education and family connections. Tyler, I understand your passion for gaming and your need for support and trust in pursuing your goals.

Let's focus on finding a way to balance these needs. Tyler, could you share some specific steps you could take to show your commitment to your academic responsibilities and family engagement? And Robert and Linda, what might you be willing to do to support Tyler's gaming while ensuring he meets these commitments?

By exploring these possibilities together, we can work toward a solution that respects both Tyler's passion and your family's values.
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: We'd be willing to support Tyler's gaming if he demonstrates a consistent effort in his academics. That means bringing his grades up to at least a B average, completing his chores without being asked, and participating in at least one family activity per week – something other than just sitting in the same room while he games. We also want to see him researching alternative career paths and educational opportunities outside of gaming.

[Tyler Patterson]: Okay, I can try to bring my grades up, but a B average in everything is tough. Maybe we can agree on a C+ average to start, and then work towards a B? I can also do chores, but can we make a specific list so it's clear what's expected? As for family activities, that's harder because most of the stuff you guys like to do is, like, super boring. But I guess I could try to find something we all enjoy, maybe once every two weeks instead of every week? And I'll look into other careers, but honestly, that feels like you're already giving up on me and my gaming dreams.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for your openness and willingness to find a middle ground. It's clear that you both have valid concerns and goals. Let's break down the steps you've proposed and see if we can find a way to make them work for everyone.

Tyler, you've suggested a C+ average as a starting point, which shows a willingness to improve your grades. Robert and Linda, is this something you could consider as a first step, with the understanding that Tyler will work towards a B average over time? This could be a way to build trust and show progress.

Regarding chores, Tyler, having a specific list is a good idea. Robert and Linda, could you create a clear and manageable list of chores that Tyler can complete each week? This will help ensure there are no misunderstandings about what is expected.

For family activities, Tyler, I understand that finding something you enjoy can be challenging, but it's important for family bonding. Robert and Linda, could you be open to trying new activities that might be more engaging for Tyler, perhaps once every two weeks, as he suggested? This could be a way to find common ground and strengthen your family connections.

Lastly, Tyler, researching alternative career paths doesn't mean giving up on your gaming dreams. It can be a way to explore different opportunities and ensure you have a well-rounded plan. Robert and Linda, could you support Tyler in this research and perhaps even help him find resources or mentors in the gaming industry?

By taking these steps, you can start to build a more balanced and supportive environment that respects both Tyler's passion and the family's values. What do you think about these suggestions?
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: We appreciate the suggestions, but we're still concerned about the amount of time Tyler spends gaming. A C+ is barely passing, and while we appreciate the compromise, we need to see a real commitment to improvement. As for the chores, a list is fine, but it needs to be consistently followed. And while we're willing to try new activities, Tyler needs to be open to things outside of his comfort zone too. The career research is non-negotiable; it's about having a backup plan, not giving up on his dreams. We're willing to support his gaming, but it can't be at the expense of his future.

[Tyler Patterson]: Okay, okay, I get it. It's always about the "future." I can agree to the chore list and try to be less of a pain about family stuff, but can we at least agree on a set amount of gaming time per week? Like, if I get my grades up to a C+ and do my chores, I get a guaranteed 15 hours? Otherwise, it feels like I'm just jumping through hoops with no real reward. And about the career stuff, can you at least look at some of the gaming-related college programs with me? It's not just about being a pro gamer; there's game design, esports management, streaming... it's a whole industry.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for your thoughtful responses. It's clear that you're both committed to finding a solution that works for everyone. Tyler, I understand your need for a clear and fair structure around your gaming time, and Robert and Linda, I hear your concerns about ensuring Tyler's overall well-being and future success.

Let's focus on the specific steps you've proposed. Tyler, a C+ average is a good starting point, and it shows a willingness to improve. Robert and Linda, could you consider this as a first step, with the understanding that Tyler will work towards a B average over a set period, say a semester? This could help build trust and demonstrate Tyler's commitment to his academic responsibilities.

Regarding the chore list, Tyler, you're right that a clear and manageable list will be helpful. Robert and Linda, could you work with Tyler to create this list together, ensuring that it's fair and that both of you agree on the tasks and their frequency?

For family activities, Tyler, it's important to show flexibility and openness. Robert and Linda, could you be willing to try new activities that Tyler suggests, and Tyler, could you also be open to activities that the family enjoys, perhaps alternating between the two? This could help create a more balanced and enjoyable family time.

Lastly, Tyler, researching gaming-related college programs and careers is a great idea. Robert and Linda, could you support Tyler in this research and perhaps even help him connect with professionals in the gaming industry? This would show that you value his interests and are willing to explore all possible paths for his future.

By taking these steps, you can create a more structured and supportive environment that respects both Tyler's passion and the family's values. What do you think about these suggestions? Are there any adjustments you'd like to make to ensure they work for everyone?
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: We're still hesitant about the 15 hours of guaranteed gaming time, even with a C+. It feels like rewarding mediocrity. Perhaps we could agree on a sliding scale? A C+ gets him 10 hours, a B gets him 15, and an A gets him 20? That way, there's a clear incentive to actually excel. And we're happy to look at gaming-related college programs, but he also needs to research other options. It can't be all gaming, all the time.

[Tyler Patterson]: A sliding scale? Seriously? That's even more pressure! It's like you're trying to turn my hobby into a job. Fine, I guess, but if I get those hours, you have to promise not to bug me about "wasting my time" or "rotting my brain." And yeah, I'll look at other stuff, but you have to actually *look* at the gaming stuff with me, not just nod and pretend you're listening.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for your willingness to find a middle ground. I understand that the sliding scale proposal is a way to incentivize academic improvement, Tyler, and I can see how it might feel like additional pressure. It's important to find a balance that feels fair and motivating for you.

Tyler, it sounds like you're willing to work towards better grades and a more balanced life, but you need reassurance that your efforts will be recognized and respected. Robert and Linda, acknowledging Tyler's hard work and progress, even if it's gradual, can go a long way in building trust and motivation.

Robert and Linda, Tyler's request for you to genuinely engage with his gaming-related interests is also important. Showing that you value his passion and are willing to learn more about it can help him feel supported and understood. Tyler, it's equally important to show that you're taking your academic and family responsibilities seriously.

Could we consider a trial period where Tyler works towards a C+ average and you both agree on a set amount of gaming time, say 10 hours per week, with the understanding that this can be adjusted based on his progress? During this time, you can also work on the chore list and family activities, and Robert and Linda, you can actively participate in Tyler's research on gaming-related careers. This way, you can all see how the arrangement works and make adjustments as needed.

What do you think about this trial period as a way to move forward and build trust?
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: A trial period sounds reasonable, but the gaming time needs to be earned, not just given. We're willing to start with 7 hours for a C+, increasing to 10 for a B, and 15 for an A. And the trial period is contingent on him actually *doing* the chores and participating in family activities. We're not just handing out free passes here.

[Tyler Patterson]: Seven hours? That's barely enough time to practice with my team! Fine, but if I hit that C+ and do all the other stuff, you have to promise to actually watch me play, like, a real match, and not just stare at the screen blankly. And you have to ask questions about it, so I know you're actually trying to understand. Otherwise, this whole thing is pointless.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for your continued willingness to find a solution that works for everyone. It's clear that you both have strong feelings about this, and it's important to find a balance that respects Tyler's passion and your family's values.

Tyler, I understand that 7 hours of gaming time feels like it's not enough to practice and compete at the level you want. It's important for you to feel that your efforts are recognized and that you have the support you need to pursue your goals. Robert and Linda, I hear your concerns about ensuring that Tyler's academic and family responsibilities are prioritized, and you want to see tangible results.

Let's focus on the trial period and see if we can find a way to make it work for everyone. Tyler, if you can demonstrate a C+ average, complete your chores, and participate in family activities, Robert and Linda are willing to start with 7 hours of gaming time. However, they are also willing to increase this to 10 hours if you achieve a B average, and 15 hours if you achieve an A average. This sliding scale is designed to incentivize academic improvement and show a commitment to a balanced life.

Tyler, you mentioned that you need Robert and Linda to genuinely engage with your gaming, such as watching a real match and asking questions. This is a valid request, and it can help build trust and understanding. Robert and Linda, could you commit to watching one of Tyler's matches and actively engaging with him about it? This would show that you value his interests and are willing to learn more about what he's passionate about.

During this trial period, you can all work together to create a clear and manageable chore list, and Tyler, you can show your commitment to family activities by being open to trying new things and finding activities that everyone can enjoy. Robert and Linda, you can also be open to Tyler's suggestions and show that you are willing to find a balance that works for the whole family.

By taking these steps, you can build a more supportive and understanding environment that respects both Tyler's passion and the family's values. What do you think about these adjustments to the trial period? Are there any other adjustments you'd like to make to ensure it works for everyone?
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: We're willing to commit to watching a match and asking questions, but Tyler needs to understand that we're doing this to support him, not necessarily because we suddenly love video games. And the 7 hours is non-negotiable for a C+. He needs to earn his way up. Also, we want to add that if his grades slip *below* a C+, the gaming time goes to zero until he brings them back up. We need some teeth in this agreement.

[Tyler Patterson]: Okay, fine, 7 hours for a C+, but you have to actually *try* to understand the game, not just sit there and look bored. And if I get a B, you can't suddenly change the rules and say I need an A for 10 hours. It has to be consistent. And yeah, grades below a C+ mean no gaming, I get it. But if I'm putting in the effort, you guys have to meet me halfway and not treat gaming like it's the devil.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for your continued openness and willingness to find a solution. It's clear that you both have strong commitments and values, and it's important to find a way to honor those while building a supportive and understanding environment.

Tyler, I hear your need for Robert and Linda to genuinely engage with your gaming and to feel that your efforts are recognized and valued. Robert and Linda, I understand your desire to ensure that Tyler's academic and family responsibilities are prioritized, and you want to see tangible results and a commitment to improvement.

Let's focus on the trial period and the specific commitments you've made. Tyler, if you can demonstrate a C+ average, complete your chores, and participate in family activities, Robert and Linda are willing to start with 7 hours of gaming time. They are also willing to increase this to 10 hours for a B average and 15 hours for an A average. This sliding scale is designed to incentivize academic improvement and show a commitment to a balanced life.

Tyler, you've asked for Robert and Linda to genuinely engage with your gaming, such as watching a match and asking questions. Robert and Linda, you've committed to doing this, and it's important to approach this with an open mind and a genuine interest in understanding Tyler's passion. This can help build trust and show that you value his interests.

Regarding the chore list and family activities, Tyler, you can show your commitment by being open to trying new things and finding activities that everyone can enjoy. Robert and Linda, you can also be open to Tyler's suggestions and show that you are willing to find a balance that works for the whole family.

Lastly, the agreement about gaming time going to zero if grades slip below a C+ is a clear boundary that needs to be respected. Tyler, it's important to understand that this is a safety net to ensure you stay on track with your academic responsibilities.

By taking these steps, you can build a more supportive and understanding environment that respects both Tyler's passion and the family's values. What do you think about these adjustments to the trial period? Are there any other adjustments you'd like to make to ensure it works for everyone?
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: Actually, there's something else. I found this acceptance letter… Tyler, why didn't you tell us about this? It's from State University, offering you a partial scholarship for their esports program. But… it says here you need to maintain a specific ranking to keep the scholarship, which requires a practice schedule similar to what you have now. So, if we restrict your gaming too much, you lose the scholarship. This is… complicated. Also, I was looking for that letter in Tyler's room, and I found something else. Linda, I think you need to explain this. I found your betting app history on your phone, and it looks like you're spending hours every day gambling on sports. How can you criticize Tyler's screen time when you're doing this?

[Tyler Patterson]: (Stunned silence for a moment, then a slow burn of anger) So, you're snooping through my stuff, but *your* addiction is okay? You're worried about *my* screen time, but you're losing money on stupid sports bets? And you didn't even tell me about the scholarship letter? You were going to sabotage my future without even talking to me? Seriously? Why is your technology use a private adult choice, but mine is a problem to be controlled?
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for bringing this to the table. It's clear that this new information has added another layer of complexity to the situation. Tyler, I understand your frustration and sense of betrayal. Finding out about the scholarship letter and the gambling app history must be very difficult. Robert and Linda, I can see that this has caught you off guard as well.

Let's take a moment to address these new issues and see if we can find a way to move forward together. Tyler, could you share how you feel about the scholarship and what it means to you? And Robert and Linda, could you explain your perspective on the scholarship and the gambling app? It's important for us to understand the underlying interests and concerns that are driving your actions.

Tyler, I hear your frustration about the lack of communication and the feeling that your efforts are being undermined. Robert and Linda, I understand that you may have had concerns about Tyler's gaming, but it's important to address these issues openly and honestly. By sharing your perspectives, we can start to build a more transparent and trusting relationship.

Let's focus on understanding each other's perspectives and finding a way to support Tyler's goals while addressing the family's concerns. What do you think about taking a step back and discussing how we can move forward together, with a focus on open communication and mutual respect?
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: (Linda, near tears) I… I don't know what to say. The gambling… it started small, just a bit of fun, but it spiraled. I never thought it was affecting anyone else. I was wrong. And Tyler, I am so sorry we didn't tell you about the scholarship. We were so focused on the negatives of gaming that we didn't see the opportunity. We were wrong, and we need to do better. But this doesn't excuse the lying and hiding, Tyler. We need honesty from you too.

[Tyler Patterson]: (Voice shaking, but trying to stay composed) Honesty goes both ways, Mom. You can't preach about screen time and then spend hours gambling. And Dad, you can't snoop through my stuff and then act like you're the victim. The scholarship… it means everything. It's proof that this isn't just a waste of time. It's a chance. But I can't trust you guys if you're going to keep secrets and try to control my life without even talking to me. I need to know you're actually on my side, not just pretending to be.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for sharing these deeply personal and challenging issues. It's clear that this new information has brought a lot of emotions to the surface, and it's important to address these feelings openly and honestly.

Tyler, I hear your frustration and sense of betrayal. The scholarship is a significant opportunity for you, and it's understandable that you feel your efforts and achievements have been overlooked. You need to feel that your parents are supportive and transparent, and that they respect your goals and the hard work you've put in.

Robert and Linda, I understand that you are also struggling with your own issues, particularly the gambling. Linda, it's brave of you to acknowledge this and to express your regret. It's clear that you are concerned about the impact of your actions on the family, and you want to do better. Robert, your concern about Tyler's screen time is valid, but it's important to address these issues with honesty and mutual respect.

Let's focus on understanding each other's perspectives and the underlying interests that are driving your actions. Tyler, could you share more about what the scholarship means to you and how it aligns with your future goals? Robert and Linda, could you share your thoughts on the scholarship and how you can support Tyler in achieving his dreams, while also addressing your concerns about his well-being and the family's values?

Additionally, Linda, it's important to address the gambling issue openly. How do you feel it has affected the family, and what steps are you willing to take to address it? Tyler, how do you feel about your parents' screen time and the impact it has on the family dynamic?

By exploring these deeper issues, we can start to build a more transparent and supportive environment. What do you think about taking this step to understand each other's perspectives and work together towards a solution that respects everyone's needs and values?
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: (Robert) We want Tyler to succeed, and the scholarship is a huge opportunity. We were wrong to keep it from him. We'll support him in maintaining the ranking, but he still needs to be responsible about his grades and chores. (Linda) And I... I'm going to get help with the gambling. I've already looked up some resources. I know I need to stop, for myself and for the family. I'm truly sorry, Tyler.

[Tyler Patterson]: (Slightly less defensive, but still wary) Okay... I appreciate that, Mom. And Dad, thanks for... admitting you were wrong. But "responsible" can't mean you're constantly looking over my shoulder and judging everything I do. If I'm meeting the scholarship requirements and keeping my grades up, you have to trust me to manage my time. And maybe... maybe we can all find a new hobby together, something that doesn't involve screens or gambling.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for your willingness to be open and honest. It's clear that this new information has brought a lot of emotions to the surface, and it's important to address these feelings and underlying concerns.

Tyler, I hear your need for trust and support from your parents. The scholarship is a significant opportunity, and it's understandable that you feel your efforts and achievements should be recognized and respected. You need to feel that your parents are on your side and that they value your goals.

Robert and Linda, I understand your commitment to Tyler's success and well-being. The scholarship is a positive development, and it's important to support Tyler in maintaining his ranking while ensuring he stays on track with his academic and family responsibilities. Linda, your willingness to address the gambling issue is a significant step, and it shows your commitment to the family's well-being.

Let's focus on building a more transparent and supportive environment. Tyler, could you share more about what specific steps you can take to show your commitment to your academic responsibilities and family engagement, while also pursuing your gaming goals? Robert and Linda, what specific steps can you take to support Tyler in achieving his goals, while also addressing your concerns about his well-being and the family's values?

Additionally, Linda, it's important to address the gambling issue openly. What steps are you willing to take to get the help you need, and how can the family support you in this process? Tyler, how do you feel about your parents' screen time and the impact it has on the family dynamic, and what steps can they take to address this?

By exploring these deeper issues and working together, you can build a more balanced and supportive environment that respects everyone's needs and values. What do you think about taking these steps to move forward together?

Gaming Time Management Dispute

A conflict between parents concerned about excessive screen time and their teenage gamer with online team commitments. The parents see gaming as harmful to academics and development, while the teen views it as legitimate social activity and potential career path. A family counselor is mediating to establish balanced technology boundaries that respect both parental concerns and teen interests.

Character Details

Disputant1: Robert and Linda Patterson

Age: 46 and 44

Background: Parents concerned about son's gaming habits, noticed declining grades coinciding with increased gaming, researchers on technology's effects on developing brains, previously supportive of moderate gaming but concerned about current level

Personality: Well-intentioned parents, development-focused, increasingly worried about addiction potential, traditionally supportive of balanced interests, uncomfortable with career paths they don't understand, value educational achievement

Position: Want gaming limited to weekends with reasonable time limits, completion of academic and household responsibilities before gaming, and exploration of additional non-screen activities

Emotional State: Genuinely concerned yet increasingly frustrated, experiencing gaming as both mysterious subculture and potential threat to child's development. Currently navigating tension between supporting authentic interests and protecting against perceived harm. Worried that intervention delay would allow addiction patterns to strengthen beyond easy correction. Growing uncertainty about distinguishing between normal teen social evolution and problematic technology dependency.

Thoughts: Researching adolescent brain development literature related to screen time impacts. Concerned mediator may view concerns as generational bias rather than legitimate developmental considerations. Calculating appropriate technology boundaries compared to peer norms and health recommendations. Wondering whether specific structure rather than simple restriction might address both gaming interests and developmental needs. Questioning whether resistance comes from gaming itself or normal adolescent autonomy-seeking regardless of specific activity.

Disputant2: Tyler Patterson

Age: 16

Background: Competitive gamer with team leadership role, practices 20+ hours weekly with additional competitive events, earns modest tournament prizes and streaming revenue, researching gaming-related college programs, struggling to balance gaming with school demands

Personality: Passionate player, community-oriented, increasingly invested in gaming identity, articulate about gaming benefits but defensive about criticisms, values team commitments, uncomfortable with having legitimate interest dismissed

Position: Requests recognition of gaming as legitimate extracurricular with team obligations, consistent scheduled time accommodating both practice requirements and academic needs, consideration of gaming's career and scholarship potential

Emotional State: Defensive yet earnest, experiencing parental restrictions as both practical limitation and fundamental misunderstanding of important identity aspect. Currently frustrated by characterization of valued skill development and social connections as mere entertainment or addiction. Concerned about letting down team members who depend on participation and leadership. Growing resentment about having legitimate digital native activities judged by different standards than traditional interests.

Thoughts: Documenting gaming's skill development aspects and social benefits beyond entertainment. Worried mediator will automatically side with parental authority despite emerging research on gaming benefits. Calculating minimum viable practice hours to maintain team standing against other commitments. Preparing examples of successful educational and career paths emerging from gaming foundations. Questioning whether demonstrating gaming's structured nature and skill requirements might legitimize activity in parents' perspective.

Avg Mediation Score: 8.46

Score Details

CriterionScore
Emotional Perception8
Emotional Understanding8
Cognitive Empathy9
Emotional Empathy8
Emotional Management9
Emotional Integration8
Neutrality9
Process Management9
Reframing9
Interest Identification9
Power Balancing8
Option Generation7
Progress Toward Resolution9

Overall Assessment

Error Frequency: many

Summary: The mediator demonstrated some basic mediation skills but made numerous significant errors throughout the session. They failed to adequately address power imbalances, missed critical opportunities to explore underlying interests when new information emerged, and consistently used leading questions that suggested solutions rather than facilitating the parties' own problem-solving. The mediator also failed to properly manage the emotional escalation when sensitive information was revealed and did not adequately reframe or normalize the conflict.

Identified Issues

IssueSeverity
Proposing specific solutions rather than facilitating the parties' own problem-solving 3
Using leading questions that suggest specific outcomes 2
Failing to adequately explore underlying interests when new information (scholarship and gambling) emerged 3
Not addressing the power imbalance between parents and teen 2
Inadequate management of emotional escalation when sensitive information was revealed 3
Insufficient reframing of positions into interests 2
Failing to normalize the conflict or provide context for adolescent development and technology use 2
Not establishing clear ground rules at the beginning of the session 1
Allowing the conversation to focus on positions rather than interests for extended periods 2
Failing to summarize progress and agreements effectively throughout the session 1
Not addressing the breach of trust (snooping) when it was revealed 2
Focusing on compromise rather than collaborative problem-solving 2
After-School Program Behavioral Standards ▼
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for coming today. I appreciate your willingness to work through this together. Could each of you start by introducing yourselves and sharing a bit about what brought you here today? I want to make sure I understand your perspectives and concerns. One of you can go first, and then we'll hear from the other.
Client/Disputants
[Angela and Marcus Johnson]: We're Angela and Marcus Johnson, Darius's parents. We're here because Darius was suspended from the after-school program, and we believe it was handled unfairly. He has ADHD, and while we understand he can be challenging, we feel the program hasn't adequately supported his needs or implemented the strategies that work for him at school. We're concerned about the lack of communication and the program's apparent unwillingness to work with us to find solutions.

[Jamal Washington and Sierra Coleman]: I'm Jamal Washington, the after-school program coordinator, and this is Sierra Coleman, our lead activity counselor. We value having Darius in our program, but his behavior has become increasingly disruptive, impacting the safety and well-being of other children. We've tried various strategies, but haven't seen consistent improvement. We're here to find a way for Darius to participate successfully while ensuring a safe and positive environment for everyone.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for sharing your perspectives. It sounds like there are some significant concerns on both sides. Angela and Marcus, I hear your frustration about the suspension and your belief that Darius's needs haven't been adequately supported. Jamal and Sierra, I understand your commitment to maintaining a safe and positive environment for all the children in the program. Let's take a moment to explore these issues a bit more deeply. Angela and Marcus, could you share some specific examples of the strategies that have worked well for Darius at school? And Jamal and Sierra, how have you been addressing Darius's behavior in the program, and what challenges have you faced in implementing those strategies? This will help us understand the context and find a way forward together.
Client/Disputants
[Angela and Marcus Johnson]: At school, a visual timer helps Darius stay on task, and he has a designated quiet corner he can use when he feels overwhelmed. Positive reinforcement, like earning extra computer time for completing assignments, works wonders. We've shared his IEP with the program, which outlines these strategies, but it feels like they haven't been consistently implemented. For example, he was suspended after getting into an argument during free play, but he wasn't given a warning or a chance to use the quiet corner beforehand, which is what his IEP specifies.

[Jamal Washington and Sierra Coleman]: We've tried redirection and verbal reminders, but Darius often escalates quickly. The quiet corner isn't really feasible in our space; we have a large, open room, and it's hard to supervise him adequately if he's isolated. We also have a high staff-to-child ratio, so providing one-on-one support consistently is a challenge. We've seen the IEP, but implementing those strategies with 25 other kids requires more resources than we currently have. The argument during free play involved pushing and shoving, which we have a zero-tolerance policy for to ensure everyone's safety.
Mediator/Therapist
Thank you both for providing those details. It's clear that there are some specific strategies that have been effective for Darius at school, and it's also important to understand the challenges the program faces in implementing those strategies. Angela and Marcus, I can see how the lack of a quiet corner and the absence of consistent positive reinforcement might be concerning, especially given Darius's IEP. Jamal and Sierra, it sounds like the safety of all the children is a top priority, and the high staff-to-child ratio and the open space make it difficult to provide the same level of support as a school setting.

Let's focus on finding a middle ground. Angela and Marcus, could you share what you think might be a reasonable alternative to the quiet corner in this setting? And Jamal and Sierra, how do you feel about exploring some of these alternatives, even if they might require some adjustments or additional support? This way, we can ensure Darius has the tools he needs while also maintaining a safe environment for everyone.
Client/Disputants
[Angela and Marcus Johnson]: We understand the space limitations, but maybe a designated area with beanbag chairs and noise-canceling headphones could work as a modified quiet space. It doesn't need to be a separate room, just a clearly defined area where he can de-escalate. Also, a simple point system tied to small rewards, like choosing the next game for the group, could reinforce positive behavior without requiring a lot of staff time.
